patterns.title: Unauthorized storage access via stolen credentials
patterns.description: An attacker obtains storage service credentials such as access keys, shared access signatures, or service account tokens through code repository exposure, social engineering, or compromised CI/CD pipelines. These credentials grant the attacker the ability to impersonate a legitimate service and access stored data.
common_mitigations: Use IAM roles and instance profiles instead of long-lived access keys
Implement automatic credential rotation with short expiry periods
Monitor for credential usage from unusual locations or IP addresses
Enable secret scanning in code repositories to detect leaked credentials
Use temporary credentials with least-privilege scoping for all storage operations

patterns.title: Stored data modification without integrity checks
patterns.description: Files or objects in storage are modified without detection because the system does not maintain or verify integrity checksums. An attacker who gains write access can alter stored data such as configuration files, uploaded documents, or backups without triggering any alerts or validation failures.
common_mitigations: Implement content integrity verification using cryptographic checksums such as SHA-256
Enable object versioning to maintain a history of changes and allow rollback
Use write-once or immutable storage policies for critical data
Implement change detection alerts that notify administrators of unexpected modifications
Apply digital signatures to critical stored artifacts to verify authenticity

patterns.title: Missing storage access logging
patterns.description: Storage access events such as reads, writes, and deletions are not logged, making it impossible to determine who accessed or modified specific files. Without access logging, incident response teams cannot trace data breaches, and organizations cannot demonstrate compliance with data access audit requirements.
common_mitigations: Enable server access logging or data event logging on all storage resources
Forward storage access logs to a centralized log management and SIEM system
Configure log retention policies that meet organizational and regulatory requirements
Implement alerting on anomalous access patterns such as bulk downloads or deletions
Protect log integrity by storing logs in a separate, restricted account or service

patterns.title: Public bucket/container exposure
patterns.description: Cloud storage buckets or containers are configured with public access permissions, allowing anyone on the internet to list and download stored objects. This is one of the most common causes of large-scale data breaches, frequently exposing sensitive customer data, internal documents, or database backups.
common_mitigations: Enable account-level public access blocking to prevent accidental public exposure
Use infrastructure-as-code to enforce private-by-default storage configurations
Implement continuous monitoring for publicly accessible storage resources
Conduct regular automated scans to detect misconfigured storage permissions
Apply bucket policies that explicitly deny public access except for intentionally public content

patterns.title: Missing encryption at rest for stored files
patterns.description: Files and objects stored in cloud or on-premises storage are not encrypted at rest. If the underlying storage media is compromised through physical theft, unauthorized snapshot access, or insider threat, all stored data is immediately readable without any decryption barrier.
common_mitigations: Enable server-side encryption with service-managed or customer-managed keys
Implement client-side encryption for highly sensitive data before uploading
Use a key management service with automatic key rotation and access controls
Enforce encryption-at-rest policies through infrastructure-as-code and compliance checks

patterns.title: Pre-signed URL abuse (long expiry)
patterns.description: Pre-signed URLs for accessing private storage objects are generated with excessively long expiration periods. If a pre-signed URL is shared, leaked, or intercepted, anyone who obtains it can access the referenced object for the entire validity period without any additional authentication or authorization checks.
common_mitigations: Set pre-signed URL expiration times to the minimum required duration, ideally minutes not hours
Log all pre-signed URL generation events with the requesting user and expiry details
Implement URL usage tracking to detect sharing or abnormal access patterns
Use one-time-use download tokens instead of pre-signed URLs for sensitive content

patterns.title: Storage quota exhaustion
patterns.description: An attacker uploads a large volume of data to fill available storage capacity, causing legitimate write operations to fail. This can disrupt application functionality that depends on storage availability, including log collection, user file uploads, backup operations, and data processing pipelines.
common_mitigations: Implement per-user and per-application upload quotas and file size limits
Monitor storage utilization and configure alerts at defined threshold levels
Implement lifecycle policies to automatically archive or delete aged data
Use rate limiting on upload endpoints to prevent rapid storage consumption
Separate critical storage resources from user-facing upload targets

patterns.title: Hotlinking/bandwidth abuse
patterns.description: External websites or applications directly link to stored resources, consuming bandwidth and increasing costs without authorization. High-traffic hotlinking can exhaust bandwidth allocations, degrade performance for legitimate users, and result in unexpected storage egress charges.
common_mitigations: Implement referrer-based access controls to restrict which domains can link to stored content
Use a CDN with hotlink protection and bandwidth throttling capabilities
Serve content through application-controlled endpoints rather than direct storage URLs
Monitor egress traffic patterns and alert on unexpected bandwidth spikes

patterns.title: Overly permissive storage IAM policies
patterns.description: Storage access policies grant broader permissions than required, such as full read-write access to all buckets when only read access to a specific prefix is needed. Overly permissive policies increase the impact of any credential compromise and may allow lateral movement to access data across organizational boundaries.
common_mitigations: Apply the principle of least privilege with resource-level and condition-based IAM policies
Use separate IAM roles for different application functions with scoped storage permissions
Implement IAM Access Analyzer or equivalent tools to identify overly permissive policies
Conduct regular IAM policy reviews and remove unused or excessive permissions
Use service control policies or permission boundaries to set maximum permission limits

patterns.title: Cross-account storage access
patterns.description: Storage resources are accessible from other cloud accounts due to misconfigured cross-account access policies or overly broad resource-based policies. An attacker who compromises a different account in the organization can leverage cross-account trust to access sensitive storage resources they should not have permission to reach.
common_mitigations: Restrict cross-account access to explicitly approved accounts and roles only
Use organization-level SCPs to prevent unauthorized cross-account resource sharing
Implement condition keys in resource policies to limit access by organization ID or account
Regularly audit cross-account access configurations and trust relationships
Use VPC endpoints and private networking to limit storage access to approved network paths
